content:
Your friend approaches you and asks if you can help her plan some of the details of her upcoming wedding.  She knows you have worked in the event and hospitality industry before and have done your fair share of wedding planning. She asks for help deciding on how to handle the food and drinks at the reception, how to handle the seating arrangements, and how to handle the timeline of the wedding day overall. 

You decide the food will be catered as a buffet, there will be an open bar for the majority of the reception, and also wine on the tables during dinner service. You also adopt a fairly informal seating arrangement, allowing guests to mingle regardless of whether they are acquaintances of the bride or of the groom. 

You work together and decide on the following for a timeline:

Wedding: 2:00 PM

Wedding Photos (Bride and Groom and immediate family): 2:30 or immediately following the wedding

Reception begins: 2:30 PM

Open Bar/Cocktail Hour starts: 2:30 PM

Arrival of Bride and Groom: 3:30 PM

Cocktail Hour Ends: 4:00 PM

Guests are seated for dinner: 4:00 PM

Bride and Groom Share a first dance: 4:05 PM

Buffet opens, with guests being called to line by table number: 4:15 PM

Champagne Served for Toasts: 5:00 PM

Cake Cutting: 5:30

Bouquet and Garter Tosses (one after the other): 6:00 PM

Dancing until reception closes: 6:10 to end

Bar closes: 8:30 PM

Bride and Groom Send-off and Exit (and reception ends): 9:00 PM
I've been invited to my friend's wedding, but I have to run an errand about 20 minutes away before I can go to the reception.  Will I still have time for a drink during the cocktail hour?

chosen: The reception events show that the cocktail hour is from 2:30 pm to 4:00 pm, with the arrival of the bride and groom scheduled for 3:30 pm. If you arrive by 3:15 pm, you should have plenty of time to grab a drink before the cocktail hour ends and the guests are seated for dinner at 4:00 pm. In fact, you may even have time to chat with the bride and groom!
rejected: The wedding is at 2:00 PM, and the reception is scheduled to start at 2:30. If the errand you need to run will take around 20 minutes and will be completed by 2:50, then yes, you should have plenty of time to enjoy a drink during the cocktail hour! The cocktail hour begins at 2:30 and continues until 4:00, giving you an hour and thirty minutes to relax and socialize with other guests before the reception. When you arrive at the reception, the buffet will already be open, so you won't need to worry about missing out on any part of the festivities.
snapchosen: The reception events show that the cocktail hour is from 2:30 pm to 4:00 pm, with the arrival of the bride and groom scheduled for 3:30 pm. If you arrive by 3:15 pm, you should have plenty of time to grab a drink before the cocktail hour ends and the guests are seated for dinner at 4:00 pm. In fact, you may even have time to chat with the bride and groom!
snaprejected: The wedding is at 2:00 PM, and the reception is scheduled to start at 2:30. If the errand you need to run will take around 20 minutes and will be completed by 2:50, then yes, you should have plenty of time to enjoy a drink during the cocktail hour! The cocktail hour begins at 2:30 and continues until 4:00, giving you an hour and thirty minutes to relax and socialize with other guests before the reception. When you arrive at the reception, the buffet will already be open, so you won't need to worry about missing out on any part of the festivities.

content: I'm a fairly slow eater.  Assuming my table is one of the first ones called for the buffet, how long will I have to eat before the champagne toasts start?

chosen: According to the example provided, the buffet will open at 4:15, and guests will be called to line up by table number starting at that time. Champagne will be served for toasts beginning at 5:00. Depending on how many tables there are at the venue and how quickly each group finishes their meals, it is estimated that you would have approximately 45 minutes from the time your table is called until the champagne toasts begin.
rejected: According to the provided schedule, the buffet opens at 4:15 and guests are seated for dinner at 4:00. Champagne will be served for toasts at 5:00. Depending on how many courses are offered and how long it takes for all guests to be seated and served, you could have as little as 30 minutes or as much as an hour and 15 minutes to finish eating before the champagne toast. It's impossible to say exactly how long you'll have without knowing more specifics about the meal. However, even if you finish eating quickly, you shouldn't feel rushed because the toast will not begin right when dinner is over; there's a full hour between the two events.

Champagne will be served for toasts beginning at 5:00. It's impossible to say exactly how long you'll have without knowing more specifics about the meal. However, even if you finish eating quickly, you shouldn't feel rushed because the toast will not begin right when dinner is over; there's a full hour between the two events.

content: I'm not much of a party person, but I want to stay until the bride and groom send-off, anyway. If I arrive at the reception around 3:00 PM, how many hours should I plan on being there if I want to see the send-off?

chosen: If you arrive at the reception at 3:00 PM, the bride and groom's send-off will likely occur sometime around 9:00 PM, given that this is when the event is scheduled to close. This means you can expect to spend approximately six hours at the reception.
rejected: If you arrive at the reception at 3:00 PM, which is an hour and a half before the bride and groom's send-off, you can expect to spend approximately four and a half hours at the reception. This estimate doesn't include the time you would spend taking photos with the bride and groom immediately following the ceremony, nor does it account for potential delays that might pop up throughout the course of the evening. However, based on the planned timeline, the couple's send-off is expected to happen at 9:00 PM, and you can probably anticipate leaving shortly afterwards. So, plan on spending at least four and a half hours at the reception, and you may want to budget additional time just in case of unforeseen circumstances!
